review.title: Helping Domain Experts Build Speech Translation Systems
review.abstract: We present a new platform, "Regulus Lite", which supports rapid development and web deployment of several types of phrasal speech translation systems using a minimal formalism. A distinguishing feature is that most development work can be performed directly by domain experts. We motivate the need for platforms of this type and discuss three specific cases: medical speech translation, speech-to-sign-language translation and voice questionnaires. We briefly describe initial experiences in developing practical systems.

sections.heading: 1 Introduction and motivation
sections.text: In this book, we claim that there is a place for limited, rule-based speech systems that have more expression than fixed phrases, but less expression than general syntax-based transfers or interlingua architectures. We want it to be possible to construct these systems using a formalism that allows for much of the work and produces the result instantly. To this end, we describe a new platform, "Regulus Lite," that can be used to develop multiple types of spoken language applications. sections.heading: 3.1 Medical translation
sections.text: As already mentioned, medical language translation is one of the areas that most motivates our architecture. Several studies, including previous projects of our own [23,30], suggest that physicians are doubtful about the unpredictability of diversified SMT systems and place a high value on translations previously validated by professional translators. Other relevant factors are that medical diagnostic dialogues are sterotypical and highly structured, and that the languages that pose practical difficulties are poorly served by established translation systems.The practical problems arise from the fact that Lite formalism only supports regular expression translations, so the question is which constituents we can find, which it is always safe to translate compositively. It is clear that many constituents cannot be treated in this way. Nevertheless, it turns out that enough of them can be translated compositively, that grammatical description is vastly more efficient than a completely transformative framework, and most of them can be treated as medical adjectives, especially PPs, and adjectives.

sections.heading: 3.3 Voice questionnaires
sections.text: The general purpose of the questionnaire is to add voice input and output capacities to the questionnaire frame. [26] The questionnaire definition encodes a branched sequence of questions, with the identity of the following question determined by the answer to the previous one. The display shows the person administering the questionnaire the field that is being filled in; they formulate a question and speak it in their own language. Generally, there are many questions that can be used to fill in a specific field, and the interviewer will select an appropriate one depending on the situation. A basic choice that affects most fields is between a GH and a Y / N question. For example, if the interviewer can see recently used cooking utensils in front of him, it is strange to ask the open GH question that requires cooking.

sections.heading: 4 Initial evaluation
sections.text: The initial AidSLT questionnaire was tested between March and July 2015 by seven humanitarian workers with practical experience and knowledge of household surveys, focusing on the recognition of voice input by English-speaking interviewers. Subjects were presented with a simulation exercise consisting of submitting a household survey on malaria prevention to an imaginary French-speaking respondent. Instructions were sent by e-mail in the form of a PDF file. Subjects logged in via the Internet at various locations with password-protected accounts. Each subject completed the questionnaire once; comments were inserted into the script, resulting in a popup asking the subjects to reformulate their initial questionnaire. We received a total of 137 correctly logged interactions7, which were independently commented by two judges. Annotators were asked to transcribe the recorded comments and answer two questions: whether the 86 percent of the questionnaire appeared to be correctly answered or whether the 79 percent was correctly answered.
